title: Date when most Brits turn the heating on - and how to avoid paying massive bills
text:

Autumn is in the air and the temperature's starting to fall - which means for many, it's time to crank up the thermostat.

But with the chill only just creeping in, is it too soon to be sending your energy bills into overdrive?

It's a question millions of households will be asking themselves this week as the so-called Indian Summer starts to fizzle out - so we decided to ask the experts.

"Generally, in the UK, the heating goes back on for winter in mid to late October and the switch-on normally takes place on a weekend, when everyone is home," explained Sally Jaques, from GoCompare Energy.

Statistically, households tend to turn up the heating in the weeks leading up to the change in the clocks, Jaques explains - this is when the National Grid tends to see a surge in usage, and typically when the nights start to get cooler.

But according to switching service Migrate, there's an actual date that Brits will be turning on their heating - and it's just around the corner.

"Our research found that Saturday 17 October will be the date where Britain finally caves and dials up the thermostat, and their energy usage," George Chalmers, at Migrate said.

He added that while 40% of people are delaying switching on their heating on due to the cost of heating their home, Saturday October 17 will be the 'big turn on' in the UK.

But that's only for the typical bill payer - with those on pre-payment meters expected to hold out for almost four weeks longer - until Friday, November 1.

However, there may be a way around those eye-watering bills.

"The winter is where we use the most energy, between heating our homes and generally spending more time inside using electricity, so being on a poor value tariff can have a huge impact on your bills," Chalmers explained.

"With the nights closing in and the weather getting colder and wetter, time’s running out to switch to a better energy deal before the winter officially arrives."

(Image: Getty)

Migrate estimates that the average family could save £315 a year by switching to the next best energy tariff for their home .

This also applies to those whose bills are covered by the energy price cap - which last week knocked an average of £75 a year off for those on standard variable tariffs.

"With a £315 difference between the price cap and the cheapest deal currently on the market, customers still on a capped standard variable tariff will pay nearly £30 a week more to heat their homes than those who have migrated supplier.

"So, unless you have money to burn this winter, make sure you get online and switch your tariff before you switch on the heating."

GoCompare agrees.

It estimates that 11million UK households are currently paying too much for their gas and electric because they're on a default tariff.

"There is still time to switch to a better deal for this winter and start saving money almost immediately," Jaques said.

description: One person 10 has already switched their heating on due to cold weather - but here's when everyone else will be caving in
